results.notes:
Three specimens, two older and one in its middle-aged prime. They are absolutely classic bicolor to my eye, albeit a bit faded in the cap from direct exposure to sunlight. The oldest of the three was discarded later on and is not in the herbarium sample.

Found under oak. The colors are true if you account for a bit of glare from very bright and direct sunlight.

The pores quickly stained blue when bruised. The blue persisted until a few hours later when it finally evolved to brown. The older specimens blued quicker and more profoundly than the midlife one, which may be an identifying trait compared to Observation 321391 (in that observation the pores of the younger specimens blued more readily).

Mycelium was pale yellowish white. Or maybe just white.

The red of the stipe is formed in typical streaks rather than spots or the like.

Stem context was obvious yellow, becoming noticeably paler in the caps. Larval tunnels were dark red.

Cap texture was typical of boletes, with the older specimen being much softer and more marshmallowy. The flesh did not turn blue in any notable way except for a region right above the stipe (photo taken).

MEASUREMENTS

Biggest cap diameter = 15 cm
Biggest cap thickness = 5 cm
Biggest cap tubes = 1 cm
Overall height = 12 cm, but with a sharply curved bottom

Midlife cap diameter = 7 cm.
Midlife cap thickness = 2 cm
Midlife cap tubes = 1/2 cm
Midlife Overall height = 9-1/2 cm

CHEMICAL TESTS

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No strong reaction on the older specimen. Midlife specimen developed a darker red spot with a dark gray aura.
Ammonia on Context: No strong reaction on the older specimen. Midlife specimen turned gray.
Ammonia on Pores: No strong reaction on either specimen.

KOH on Cap Skin: No strong reaction on the older specimen. Midlife specimen might have turned a little red.
KOH on Context: Orange on both specimens.
KOH on Pores: Orange/red on the older specimen. Midlife specimen had no strong reaction.

FeSO4 on Cap Skin: Olive on both specimens.
FeSO4 on Context: Weak olive on the large specimen, with a stronger reaction on the midlife specimen.
FeSO4 on Pores: Olive on both specimens.

Habitat: mountain mixed wood; Fagus sylvatica, Fraxinus ornus, Ostrya carpinifolia and Picea abies dominant trees; moderately inclined mountain slope, southeast aspect; calcareous, colluvial ground; fungus found on a thicker branch in a large pile of firewood cut down in the neighborhood waiting to be cut to smaller logs; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 600 m (1.970 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: dead Fagus sylvatica branch.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Libertella faginea is the name used for anamorph, asexual form of quite common fungus Eutripella quaternata = Quaternaria quaternata (teleomorph form). The fungus belongs to ascomycetes. Sexual form looks like numerous black dots on bark of some deciduous trees. Most often it is seen on Fagus.
Acervuli of the anamorph form are conspicuously saffron-yellow to orange and of quite different form. Conidia comes from beneath the bark in the form of highly gelatinous ‘tooth paste’ squeezed through tiny cracks in the bark. These tendrils and ribbons, sometimes of quite bizarre form (see Ref.4.) are essentially without internal structure under the microscope and consist of jelly like mass crowded with zillions of very thin, strongly curved (sometimes up to the form of half circle) conidia. After rain these tendrils dissolve and disappear completely from the bark surface. If one puts a piece of such infected branch in a small amount of water, the water becomes milky orange after a while. Under the microscope a single drop of this ‘solution’ shows astonishingly numerous conidia. This fungus is a common invader of drought damaged Fagus sylvatica and could well be involved in the death of the bark (Ref.6). Allegedly this is the first record of anamorph form of this species in Slovenia (at least according to Ref.5.).

Nikon D700 / Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Description of the (more) mature mushroom of the pair found:
Cap: 8 cm in diameter, slightly depressed in the center, with geometric warts that are bluish grey on the outside and more whitish in their center, cap overall dry and smooth and shiny; prominent striate margin, about 1.5 cm wide
Gills: about 13 gills per cm, free from the stem, maybe the faintest bluish or greyish hue to them
Stem: 13 cm long, somewhat clavate, tapering at the apex, 8 mm by the cap and 1.2 cm by the base, no ring, powdery coating that can be rubbed off, small zigzaggy brown or grey markings (even more prominent on smaller specimen), dry and shiny
Base: remnants of a volva, dark grey-blue in color
General: overall darker, grayer, bluer, and more striking than other Amanita vaginata specimens I’ve seen

results.notes:
These minuscule mushrooms were growing at a lake shore among Aulacomnium palustre (ribbed bog moss),
in a Pinus contorta murrayana (lodgepole pine) forest, at 2735 meter (~9000’) elevation.
They were about 8 mm (0.3 inch) tall and their cap diameter was about 4 mm (0.15 inch).

I looked at a number of families and genera, including:
Hygrophoraceae (Cantharellula, Hygrocybe, Hygrophorus)
Tricholomataceae (Myxomphalia, Pseudoomphalina, etc.)
Repetobasidiaceae (Contumyces(no CA records), Rickenella)
Marasmiaceae (Clitocybula)
but haven’t found any match yet …

Any pointers are much appreciated !

results.notes:
Suspected as suggested species by a few people. Sent to Florida for research sequencing by a student.
Sour flavor, mild scent

Cap surfaces dry/tacky to slippery/lubricated, margins striate with striations relatively shallow/indistinct. Cap color pale yellow, fading somewhat away from the disc. Universal veil occasionally deposited randomly on cap surface as variably-sized white patches/warts.

Gill attachment free to narrowly adnexed with short decurrent tooth. Short gills of variable length mainly truncate, a few attenuate.

Partial veil white, thin, fleeting, occasionally leaving a fragile ring or dropping away.

Stipe white, clavate to slightly thicker below. Stipe surface somewhat patchy-floccose. Basal volva often present as either thin white limb(s), marginate collar reminiscent of subsection Pantherinaea, or appressed white patches. Basal bulb present.

Spores (mounted in diluted Congo red) 7.5-9.5 × 7-9, with highly variable Q (globose, subglobose, broadly ellipsoid, a few verging on ellipsoid). Spores taken from both smash mount of gill material and two different prints. Spores obtained from smash showing globose nucleus (oil drop); spores from prints not showing oil drop.

Habitat for this collection is a small stand of mature Scots pine (Pinus sylvestris) with a few small oaks mixed in. No hemlock in the immediate surroundings, but hemlock present in adjacent forest. I believe I have found the same taxon in another stand of Scots pine (not far from the location for this present observation), as well as in other areas with Norway spruce.

This type mushroom typically first appears during late spring in this same location (observed since 2011), as early as the first week of June. For this reason, I had originally considered Amanita praecox as its identity. But there are several reasons for my doubting these represent praecox: 1. Lack of hemlock in the habitat; 2. Range of spore quotient well exceeds praecox; 3. Occurrence includes springtime but this type also may persist throughout the summer into October (or may disappear in summer and reappear in fall). This year (2018) these did not appear in this location early August. (I checked often June-July.) First time seeing them this year (2018) was obs 327184.

But I still wonder if “praecox” may apply to these. Another name that has been suggested is Amanita stranella.

The following collection obs 241567 was made in the same exact location as the present observation. This next collection obs 114780 comes from another stand of Scots pine a few hundred yards away from the stand of Scots pine. Spores from this latter collection mounted in KOH. Note the late collection date for the latter.

Group of fruit bodies occurs annually in this same spot, hemlock and oak most dominant.

Limbus internus may be viewed via the photo of the inner volval sac.

Classic jacksonii is not common in my area (NE PA). I had hoped to include A. banningiana in the NE PA NAMP submissions. But, this species (generally a much more locally common Caesar) has not appeared yet this summer.

En las horas del mediodia me encontre con un gran amigo. David Cruz… Conocedor de mis actividades en el Humedal y mi investigacion alrededor de los hongos me comento que había avistado un hongo a las horas de la mañana junto con su novia y lo había recolectado… Me lo mostro… Luego fuimos al lugar del avistamiento y fotografie el ejemplar en su habitat natural despues de tambien fotografear el ejemplar entregado a mi por David… Pense que era un hongo del orden de los Boletales… Para mi sorpresa el micologo Norteamericano Chael Thomas me anuncio que el hongo se trata de un Agrocybe praecox … Lo curioso es que este hongo habia sido reportado en Norte America, El Norte de Africa y Europa… Hoy 09 de Agosto del 2018 lo reportamos por primera vez para Colombia…

Los de la foto son David Cruz y su novia. Quienes descubrieran el hongo :D

results.notes:
CAP:
Color: Vivid orange in center and for about 3/4 of the mushroom, fading outwards to vidid yellow.
Size: ~10" across.
Texture: Dry & Smooth, very slimy when wet
Irregularities: 3 large lobes, almost clover-like. It looks like there could have been a 4th lobe.

PORES: Vivid yellow & deep. Stain deep blue almost immediately.

STEM: Bulbous. Yellow and orange, with faint, stretched out reticulation particularly in yellow area.

SMELL (I ain’t tastin’ that): Skunky. Very unpleasant.

CAP FLESH: Vivid yellow. Stains deep blue almost immediately.

SPORE PRINT: Olivaceous brown

HABITAT: On a mulch pile in the Florida Panhandle, <1 mile from a bay, in a very wooded, oaky yard after a week of consistent rains. Mulch pile is mixed wood, likely to be mostly oak if it’s from this area. My husband parks his car by the mulch pile, and many shrooms grow in a line beneath the back bumper where I’m sure either the heat from his exhaust creates additional warmth, or additional water drips down when it rains.

Fruiting beneath Doug fir and Western red cedar in a location I harvested from in early July(and multiple prior seasons) here in Olympia, WA, USA.

Older fruiting bodies I broke into pieces and placed inside harvest location cavities/holes to ensure repeated fruiting to come in following seasons. With Hypomyces this practice of “re-seeding” or should I say, re sporing has repeatedly given us delicious, healthy Lobsters for many, many years and I hope the money spot continues to produce using this time tested methodology. Multiple annual fruitings of Indian pipe(Monotropa uniflora) flower annually within feet of this spot(Indian pipe feed on Russula brevipes mycelium, Hypomyces’ lactufluorums favorite host to parasitize). The equation is Indian pipe=likelihood of Russula=likelihood of H. Lactifluorum). With this method one can be forecasting future harvests even during drought and off season forest walks and anticipate successful forays making note in their site notes/journal. In the same manner, Candy cane plant(Allotropa virgata is an excellent summer indicator for Matsutake(T. Magnivelare/T. Murrillianum) fruitings beginning in early October.

Terrestrial in mixed woods.

Young and old specimens harvested today and sliced to show difference in appearance from primordial stage to maturity. Many, many guidebooks only show G. oregonense at full maturity when the fruiting body is uniformly red/purple and most folks(including many mycologists) think that red, yellow and white color zonation indicates G. tsugae. Nearly all varnished Ganoderma will exhibit these tri colored patterns early in fruiting phase(during early to mid summer months) and will not become the uniform lacquered, Chinese red until full maturity. The old method for species designation using pore size analysis is also faulty and I have gone back and forth with multiple Ganoderma specialists with examples on both sides of the fence that contradict one another in terms of size. For example, a two foot wide, massive fruiting body with very dense pores(4-6 per mm) and in contrast, very small fruiting bodies(that occur on Spruce in the Hoh and Quinault rainforests that have very large pores(2-3 per mm) that most folks would macroscopically describe as similar in size to classic G. tsugae. Regardless of species identification for varnished Ganoderma(which now can easily be done using gene sequencing/DNA analysis if one is so inclined) we can all agree that each species of Ganoderma known all have myriad health benefits for human and even animal consumption.

I have monitored, harvested, analyzed, photographed, bioassayed and studied this species of fungi for nearly ten years straight now and have learned a ton from them(not only visually, but also spiritually from ingesting and making tea with them). The West coast occurring varnished Ganoderma are almost always going to be G. oregonense, At least in my home state of Washington. Most all occur on Western hemlock(I have only encountered them on Douglas fir two times out of hundreds of encounters over 10 years of research). They are a valuable resource for immune stimulation and macrophage activity and are an overall panacea(as are all Ganoderma species-worldwide). Even the often taken for granted and very common G. applanatum(artist bracket) has potent medicinal value and is packed w/benefits.

INOCULATION: I have attached images at the lower portion of this post to show what I do with cut stem butts after harvest and slicing for dehydration. Simply cut into a Western hemlock with a hatchet or hammer and bury the fresh stem butt(best to do the day of harvest if possible-but can be left in fridge overnight in a paper bag) into the tree pith/cover with bark, moss, pith and debris. This method has been a very successful one over the years and many very large, desirable strains can be easily transferrable from deep forest locales to city parks with ease(as long as the harvester makes haste with getting the stem butts inoculated).

First images show young and old fruiting bodies with notes on different uses for different stages of growth that I have found very useful over the years. Just like with many plants and other fungi, the stage of growth can render many different strengths and uses depending on the intention of the consumer.
